OUTPUT: ['Neonate - An infant from birth to approximately one month old.', 'Newborn - A baby who is newly born, usually referring to infants up to three months old.', "Babyhood - The period of time in a person's life from birth to the age when they become a child (typically around two years).", 'Toddler - An infant between approximately 1 and 2 years old who is learning to walk unaided.', "Infantile stage - A term referring to the early developmental stages in an individual's life, typically from birth up until about age three or four.", "Newborn phase - The initial period of a baby's life immediately following birth, often emphasizing physiological and developmental changes occurring during this time.", "Childhood - The early part of a person's life after infancy but before adolescence; typically refers to children between the ages of 3-12 years old.", 'Baby - A term referring to an infant, especially one who is not yet able to walk unaided.', 'Infantile growth - The rapid physical development that occurs during the early stages of life.', "Infancy - The first stage of a human's life, typically from birth up until about two years old.", "Childhood phase - A period in an individual's life characterized by being young and not yet fully developed; CLUE: Island mostly north of the Arctic circle
OUTPUT: ['Svalbard - An archipelago located in the northern part of Norway, above the Arctic Circle.', "Franz Josef Land - A group of islands located northeast of Russia's Karelia and Novaya Zemlya.", 'Severnaya Zemliya - A Russian term for "Northern Land," referring to several island groups in the Arctic, including Novaya Zemlya.', "Kolguyev Island - The largest island of Russia's Nenets Autonomous Okrug, situated north of the Arctic Circle.", 'Bear Island (Bjørnøya) - A Norwegian island located just south of the Arctic Circle, but often associated with northern territories due to its location in Svalbard.', 'Nordaustlandet - An island belonging to Svalbard and situated north of the Arctic Circle.', 'Axel Heiberg Island - A large Canadian island located within the Arctic Archipelago, above the 60th parallel but nearer to the North Pole than the Arctic Circle.', "Ellesmere Island - Part of Canada's territory that lies in the northernmost part of Canada and is close to the Arctic Circle, yet mostly north of it.", 'Devon Island - The largest uninhabited island on Earth and situated just east of the North Pole but still considered a region affected by conditions around the Arctic Circle.', 'Novaya Zemlya - A Russian archipelago located in the Arctic, known for its proximity to the north pole rather than directly above the Arctic Circle.', "Franz Joseph Land (Komsomolets Island) - One of Russia's northernmost islands that falls into the category of areas affected by conditions around the Arctic Circle.", 'Nordaustkapp - A point on Svalbard, often referred to as "North Cape," where you can observe polar night and midnight sun phenomena associated with high latitudes near the Arctic Circle.', "Kvitøya (White Island) - An island in Norway's Svalbard Archipenas a part of the region affected by conditions around the Arctic Circle.", 'Sealab - A Norwegian whaling station on Nordaustkapp, which is near but not directly above the Arctic Circle.', "White Island (Russky) - An island in Russia's Kara Sea located north of the Arctic Circle and often mentioned in discussions about polar regions.", 'Hopen - A Norwegian island situated west of Novaya Zemlya, near but not directly above the Arctic Circle.', 'Spitsbergen (Svalbard) - The largest island of Svalbard Archipelago and a part of areas impacted by conditions around the Arctic Circle.', "Severnaya Zemliya Islands - A group of islands in Russia's Kara Sea located north of the 60th parallel, near but not directly above the Arctic Circle.", 'Qeqertat (Cape Dyer) - The northernmost point of Svalbard and a region influenced by conditions around the Arctic Circle.', "Vestavikssundet Archipelago - A group of islands in Norway's Svalbard situated near but not directly above the Arctic Circle."]

['Fat Man (nuclear bomb) - The atomic bomb detonated at Nagasaki during World War II on August 9, 1945', 'Castle Bravo (nuclear test) - This was an underground nuclear test conducted by the United States on March 1, 1952, at Enewetak Atoll in the Marshall Islands and resulted in significant radioactive contamination.', 'Tsar Bomba (nuclear bomb) - The largest and most powerful nuclear weapon ever detonated during a test by the Soviet Union on October 30, 1961', 'Plutonium-239 (isotope) - A man-made radioactive isotope produced by bombarding Uranium-238 with neutrons, discovered and utilized shortly after 1952 for nuclear weapons development.', 'Hydrogen Bomb (nuclear device) - The first successful test of a hydrogen bomb took place on November 1, 1952, as Operation Ivy in the United States.', 'Uranium-238 (isotope) - Naturally occurring uranium that serves as the primary material for breeding Plutonium-239 through neutron capture processes used in nuclear weapons development around this period.', 'Neptunium-239 (nuclear isotope) - A radioactive element produced from Uranium-238 during the bombardment with neutrons, significant for creating plutonium-240 and later, Plutonium-239 in nuclear weapons.', 'Neptunium-240 (nuclear isotope) - An isotope produced from Uranium-238 during the bombardment with neutrons; it can be used as a tamper material in nuclear warheads to enhance efficiency, developed around 1952.', 'Critical Mass (nuclear physics concept) - The minimum amount of fissile material needed for a sustained nuclear chain reaction', 'Fission Products (nuclear terms) - Substances produced by nuclear reactions, especially from splitting uranium or plutonium nuclei; significant after 1952 with increased nuclear activities.', 'Enrichment Processes (nuclear procedures) - The methods used to increase the concentration of Uranium-235 in uranium, critical for developing atomic weapons since around 1952.', 'Gadget (early term for nuclear device) - Refers to the "Gadget," the code name for the world\'s first plutonium implosion-type bomb detonated in New Mexico on July 16, 1945', 'Nuclear Proliferation (nuclear term) - The spread of nuclear weapons technology to countries other than those which originally developed them; this became a significant issue following World War II, escalating in importance through the 1950s.', 'Radioactive Contamination (environmental concern) - A consequence of nuclear explosions or accidents that can have lasting impacts on ecosystems and human health; relevant to discussions post-1952, like those following Castle Bravo.', 'Criticality Accident (nuclear safety issue) - An incident in a nuclear reactor where the fissile material reaches critical mass unintentionally; while not exploded specifically in 1952, events that lead to this understanding occurred around that time.', 'Yellowcake (chemical precursor) - A concentrated form of uranium obtained from leachates during the milling process and used for further enrichment; became a significant part of nuclear material processing in the 1950s.', 'Neutron Activation Analysis (nuclear technique) - A method to determine the composition of elements within a sample, including isotopes produced from neutron capture, which were essential for developing nuclear technologies around this era.', 'Atomic Age/Era (socio-historical term) - The period following World War II during which the world experienced widespread development of atomic energy and weapons; conceptualized in the 1950s but fundamentally beginning with the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.', 'Fat Man (nuclear weapon design) - The implosion-type nuclear device that was used at Nagasaki on August 9, 1 mantle events post-1952 due to its role in advancing the knowledge and technology of atomic bombs during this period.']

['Sparrow - A small bird known for its distinct chirping sound.', "Cricket - An insect often associated with crickets' characteristic chirping sounds.", 'Robin - Another common bird species whose song is often described as a cheerful "chirp."', 'Nightingale - Famous for its powerful and melodious nighttime song, which includes chirps.', 'Wren - A small bird with a high-pitched chirping sound.', 'Woodpecker - Though not primarily known for its chirping, woodpeckers do have various calls that can include a chirp-like noise.', 'Lark - Known for their beautiful song and often described as melodic "chirps."', 'Finch - A small bird whose song is characterized by distinctive chirping sounds.', 'Titmouse - The name given to birds with a high-pitched, chatty or "teacher" like chirp sound.', 'Bluebird - Known for its sweet melodic song that often includes chirps and whistles.', 'Warbler - A diverse group of small passerine bird species with many having musical songs featuring chirping sounds.', 'Cuckoo - Although more known for their distinct "cuckoos," some cuckoo birds also produce a soft, repetitive chirp-like call.', 'Canary - Known for its sweet singing voice and the high pitch of its song that can resemble chirping sounds.', 'Tanager - A group of brightly colored South American birds whose songs include chirps and whistles.', 'Swallow - While swallows are famous for their aerial acrobatics, some species also have melodic chirping song.', 'Sage Grouse - Though not a bird but a large bird-like game animal, the male\'s courtship display can include a series of soft clucking and popping noises that might be described as "chirp" like sounds.', 'Parakeet - A type of parrot known for their cheerful chatter and song, which often includes chirping sounds.', 'Firefly - The bioluminescent insects also produce a characteristic clicking sound that can be described as "chirp" like noises when they\'re mating.', 'Mole cricket - A type of large insect with wings, which produces a series of chirping sounds during courtship rituals.', 'Pipit - Smallish grassland bird whose song often consists of short notes that can be described as "chirps."']

['Joule - A unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI), used to measure various types of energy, including thermal or heat energy from gases.', 'Calorie - The amount of heat required to raise one gram of water by one degree Celsius; commonly used as a unit for measuring energy content in food and fuels.', 'Therm (thermole) - A unit of heat representing the amount of heat released when 1 mole of a gas changes from liquid phase at its boiling point to vapor at the same temperature, often used in chemistry.', 'BTU (British thermal unit) - The amount of energy needed to raise one pound-mass of water by one degree Fahrenheit; commonly used as a unit for measuring gas and fuel heat content.', 'Erg - A small unit of energy derived from the Greek word for "energy," equal to 1 joule divided by 10^7, often used in physics calculations.', 'Calorie (small) - A smaller unit than one calorie, with a value equivalent to 4.184 Joules; commonly used in nutritional and medical contexts for measuring energy content of food or substances.', 'Heat capacity - Not strictly a unit but an important concept that measures the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a gas by one degree Celsius, depending on its mass and composition.', 'Kilocalorie (kcal) - A thousand calories; used in nutrition as a measure for food energy content and is also equivalent to 4186 Joules.', 'Thermochemistry - The branch of chemistry that studies the heat exchange associated with chemical reactions, including those involving gases.', 'Heat flux - Not an exact unit but refers to the rate at which heat energy is transferred per unit area; relevant when discussing gas-related heating processes.', "Molar heat capacity - The amount of heat required to raise one mole of a substance's temperature by one degree Celsius or Kelvin, applicable for gases under certain conditions.", 'Joule per kilogram (J/kg) - A unit that describes the specific energy associated with heating a material; in terms of gas heat content, it can be used to measure the amount of energy required to raise temperature by one degree Celsius per kilogram.', 'Watt-hour (Wh) - A unit commonly used for measuring electrical energy consumption or production and may indirectly relate to the heat produced by gases through processes like combustion.', 'British Thermal Unit (BTU): While primarily associated with heating, a BTU is also relevant in contexts involving gas-related power generation and transfer.', 'Heat of combustion: A measure of the heat energy released when a substance undergoes complete combustion; applicable for gases as well.', "Specific heat capacity - The amount of heat required to raise one gram of a substance's temperature by one degree Celsius, including gaseous states.", 'Calorimetry: Not an exact unit but refers to the study and measurement of the heat exchanged in chemical reactions or physical processes involving gases.', 'Kelvin - A base unit of thermodynamic temperature scale used by scientists worldwide, which can indirectly relate to gas-related thermal measurements.', 'Heat transfer coefficient: Not an exact unit but a parameter that measures the heat exchange efficiency between a gas and its surrounding environment in specific contexts such as HVAC systems or refrigeration processes.', 'Energy density - A measure of energy per unit volume, which may be relevant when discussing gases with high energy content or during compression/expansion phases.']
